title: How to Shrink Fibroids: Can Natural Remedies Help?

steps.title: A diet higher in fruits and leafy green vegetables reduces your risk for fibroids and might shrink existing ones.
steps.content: A diet higher in fruits and leafy green vegetables reduces your risk for fibroids and might shrink existing ones. Follow a healthy diet and build your meals around fruits and vegetables to see if this helps. [1] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source The general health advice is to eat at least 1.5-2 cups of fruit and 2-3 cups of vegetables every day. Use this as your guideline to make sure you’re getting enough. [2] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Citrus fruits in particular lower your risk for fibroids. Try to include oranges, grapefruit, lemon, lime, and tangerines in your diet.

steps.title: Some research shows that dairy products can heal fibroids.
steps.content: Some research shows that dairy products can heal fibroids. This suggests that vitamin D, calcium, and magnesium are beneficial for helping your body recover. Add more milk, cheese, and yogurt to your diet to experience these advantages. [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Have low-fat dairy products to cut fat out of your diet and avoid gaining weight.

steps.title: While all teas have antioxidants, green tea especially shows some success in treating fibroids.
steps.content: While all teas have antioxidants, green tea especially shows some success in treating fibroids. As an added bonus, a little caffeine from green tea could give you a boost. Try adding a few cups per day to your diet to see if your fibroids improve. [4] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Green tea is generally safe for use as long as you don’t have too much. The recommended amount is 2-3 cups per day, but up to 5 is safe. [5] X Research source Remember that green tea has caffeine in it, so don’t drink it close to bedtime. Get a caffeine-free type so you can sleep.

steps.title: A diet high in red meat seems to put people at a higher risk for developing fibroids.
steps.content: A diet high in red meat seems to put people at a higher risk for developing fibroids. If you eat red meat multiple times per week, then try to cut back. This might not shrink your fibroids, but it can prevent them from getting bigger and stop new ones from growing. [6] X Trustworthy Source US Office on Women's Health U.S. government agency providing resources for women's health Go to source White-meat poultry and fish are good replacements for red meat. The general advice to avoid heart disease and cancer is consuming no more than 3 red meat servings per week. This might work for you, but ask your doctor what the ideal portioning is. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Processed sugar also seems to make fibroids worse.
steps.content: Processed sugar also seems to make fibroids worse. This might be because sugar causes more insulin and estrogen to circulate in your body. Try reducing your daily sugar intake to prevent more fibroids from growing. Desserts and soda are a big source of sugar, but they aren’t the only foods with added sugars. Check all the nutrition labels when you’re buying food. You might be surprised how much sugar some foods have. The recommendation is to have no more than 25 g of added sugar per day, so keep your intake below this level. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Athletic people tend to develop fibroids less often than those who don’t exercise.
steps.content: Athletic people tend to develop fibroids less often than those who don’t exercise. If you aren’t very active, then try adding more exercise to your daily schedule. Exercise also releases hormones that reduce pain, so you could make yourself more comfortable with regular exercise as well. [9] X Research source As a general guide, the recommendation is to get 150 minutes of exercise per week. You can break this up and get 30 minutes on 5-7 days during the week. [10] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You don’t have to exercise intensely. Even a daily walk or some yard work could make a big difference.

steps.title: People with excess weight are about 2-3 times more likely to develop fibroids.
steps.content: People with excess weight are about 2-3 times more likely to develop fibroids. Being overweight can also make the pain from fibroids worse. Talk to your doctor to decide on the ideal weight for you, then design a diet and exercise routine to reach that weight. [11] X Research source Don’t try to lose weight fast with a crash or extreme diet. These are dangerous and unsustainable, and many people regain weight once they stop an extreme diet. [12] X Research source

steps.title: While stress doesn’t directly cause fibroids, it may play a role in creating them.
steps.content: While stress doesn’t directly cause fibroids, it may play a role in creating them. Specifically, stress can cause weight gain and stimulate the production of the hormone cortisol, both of which could trigger fibroids. If you regularly feel stressed out, then taking some steps to relax in your daily life could help treat your fibroids. [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Some wellness exercises like yoga, meditation, and deep breathing are good for your mental health and could reduce stress. Try spending 15-20 minutes each day on one of these activities. Doing things you enjoy is good for reducing stress as well, so make some time for your hobbies and interests each day.

steps.title: Alcoholic drinks, particularly beer, raise your risk of developing fibroids.
steps.content: Alcoholic drinks, particularly beer, raise your risk of developing fibroids. Averaging more than 1 drink per day could trigger fibroid growth, so it’s best to keep your drinking below that level. An occasional drink is fine, but don’t drink every day. [14] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Some studies show that a high vitamin D dose can reduce fibroid size.
steps.content: Some studies show that a high vitamin D dose can reduce fibroid size. These findings are preliminary, but could be a potential treatment. Try taking a daily vitamin D supplement to see if this helps. [15] X Trustworthy Source National Institutes of Health U.S. government agency for biomedical and public health research Go to source You would need a pretty high dose of vitamin D to shrink your fibroids. Since the daily recommended dose is 15 mcg, ask your doctor if taking higher doses is safe first. [16] X Research source You could also get more vitamin D from your regular diet

steps.title: While drinking green tea can help, a concentrated green tea supplement seems to work as well.
steps.content: While drinking green tea can help, a concentrated green tea supplement seems to work as well. Try taking 800 mg of green tea extract per day for 3-4 months to see if it helps. [17] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Green tea extract has caffeine as well, so be careful about taking it near bedtime. It’s best to have it earlier in the day. [18] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source Green tea extract could interact with blood thinners and beta-blockers, so ask your doctor if this is a safe treatment before you use it.

steps.title: Certain Chinese herbal mixtures show some success in reducing fibroids.
steps.content: Certain Chinese herbal mixtures show some success in reducing fibroids. The herb formula made fibroids smaller in a few small studies, so you can try it for yourself. [19] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source These were relatively small studies with inconsistent review methods, so it’s not a verified remedy. Ask your doctor before trying this treatment.

steps.title: High estrogen levels could cause fibroids.
steps.content: High estrogen levels could cause fibroids. Chasteberry supplements could reduce excess estrogen and prevent fibroids from growing. You can take the supplement in pill or liquid form. [20] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source The dosage varies for different supplement brands. For tablets, a common dose is 20-40 mg per day, and for liquid a common dose is 40 drops (about 2 ml) per day. [21] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Acupuncture may help relieve fibroid pain.
steps.content: Acupuncture may help relieve fibroid pain. While there’s no evidence that acupuncture helps specifically treat fibroids, it’s still widely used and some people find that it relieves their pain. Try this out if you’re feeling pain or discomfort with your fibroids. [22] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Always visit a licensed and experienced acupuncturist to ensure you’re getting quality treatment.
